Today I'm delighted to introduce
as our final guest speaker Been

Kim. Been Kim is a staff research
scientist at Google Brain.

If you're really
into Googleology-- those funny words at the
beginning like staff, sort of says how
senior you are--

then that means that Been's
a good research scientist. So I discovered at lunch
today that Been's started out

studying mechanical engineering
at Seoul National University, but she moved on to--

I don't know if it's
better things or not. But she moved on to computer
science and did her PhD at MIT.

And there, she started working
on the interpretability and explainability of
machine learning models.

I think she'll be talking
about some different parts of her work. But a theme that she's had in
some of her recent work that I

find especially appealing
as an NLP person is the idea that
we should be using

higher level human interpretable
languages for communication
between people and machines. So welcome, Been. Looking forward to your talk.
And go for it. Thank you. Thank you. [APPLAUSE]

Thanks for having me. It's an honor to be here. It's the rainiest Stanford
I've ever seen last night.

I got here last night. But then I live in Seattle,
so this is pretty common. So I still was able to
see the blue sky today.

And I was like, this works. I really like it here. So today I'm going to
share some of my dreams,

"Chasing my dreams to
communicate with machines." So if you're in this
class, you probably agree--

you don't have to-- that large
language models and generative models are pretty cool.

They're impressive. But you may also agree
that they're a little bit frightening.

Not just because
they're impressive, they're doing a really
good job, but also, we're

not quite sure where we're
going with this technology. In 10 years out, we
will look back and say,

that technology
was net positive? Or we will say, ah,
that was catastrophic. We didn't know that
that would happen.

Ultimately, what
I would like to do or maybe hopefully
what we all want to do

is to have this technology
benefit us humans. I know in 10 years'
time or maybe--

well, 20 years or earlier,
he's going to ask me. He's going to be like, mom,
did you work on this AI stuff?

I watched some of your talks. And did you know that
how this will profoundly

change our lives? And what did you do about that? And I have to answer
that question.

And I really hope that I have
some good things to say to him.

So my initial thought and
still so or current thought

is that if we want our ultimate
goal to benefit humanity, why not directly
optimize for it?

Why wait? So how can we benefit? There's lots of different
ways we can benefit.

But one way we can
benefit is to treat this like a colleague,
a colleague who

are really good at something. This colleague is
not perfect, but it's good at something
enough that you want

to learn something from them. One difference is,

is kind of weird.

This colleague might have

It may not care about

So you have to navigate

you first meet somebody?

There's someone so different. What do you do? You try to have a conversation

How are you beating the world

Or do you think about the

how can we work together?

really want to talk to.

And it's AlphaGo. So AlphaGo beat world Go
champion Lee Sedol in 2016.

Lee Sedol is from South Korea. I'm from South Korea. I watched every single match. It was such a big deal in South
Korea and worldwide, I hope.

And in one of the
matches, AlphaGo played this move called Move 37.

How many people watched
AlphaGo matches, and how many people
remember Move 37?

Yeah, a few people, right? And I remember the
9-dan commentator who's been talking a lot
throughout the matches suddenly

got really quiet. And he said, hm, that's
a very strange move.

And I knew then that
something really interesting has just happened
in front of my eyes,

that this is going
to change something, this AlphaGo has made

move turned around the game for AlphaGo

So Go players today continue

the move a human would fathom.

So the question
is, how did AlphaGo know this is a good move?

learn something new by communicating the

to truly figure out

is a superset of

between to exchange meaning

representational space

of what humans know. On the right, what

there will be something

like, this dog is fluffy. And you know what that

this conversation?

Our representation

So we can expand what we
